Why might it be more practical than a first preimage attack in certain scenarios? Reference NIST standards and provide examples.

distractor_protocol.step: Common misconceptions: e.g., Confuse with collision (any two messages) or first preimage (any input for hash).
Similar concepts: Swap 'second' with 'first' or 'collision'; use weak examples that actually demonstrate wrong attack.
Plausible errors: Reference real hashes incorrectly (e.g., 'SHA-1 vulnerable to second preimage' – actually collisions).
Edge cases: Outputs based on reduced complexity (e.g., 2^128 instead of 2^256 for SHA-256).
Balance: 1 superficial (typo-level), 1 conceptual mix-up, 1 advanced trap.
